results.notes:
Inocybe aff. rhacodes
An interesting observation from what it many ways looks like Inocybe rhacodes, or not quite…
The geography (~110m, coastal Portugal), ecology (next to path, on sandy clearing with small Cistaceae, not too far there were Quercus suber and Pinus pinaster) and stipippellis (pruinose all over, with abundant cystidia-like cells) are completely off from the descriptions of Bon, Kuyper, Ferrari and others.

micro notes:
-pleurocystidia common to abundant long and narrow, sometimes with belly, some sublageniform but mostly cylindrical to subcylindrical; sometimes subcapitate, poor or no crystalization; like in I. obscurobadia but thick walled!
-cheilocystidia abundant, crowded! very long and twisted narrower neck (sometimes ~250um!), sometimes shorter length, often lageniform to sublageniform often capitate, sometimes pointy apex or pointy apex after several pseudocapitate formations(spherical bulges) along neck, sometimes clearly mucronate, often septate, usually thick-walled.
-upper third caulocystidia abundant in all surface (no free space!), like cheilocystidia, maybe shorter.
-middle third pretty much the same as upper third! Maybe only a little less differentiated-complex cells, but rather similar.
-lower third not like above, but some pseudocaulocystidia present in the middle of abundant (spread on all surface) thiner and clamped and rather lactiferous terminal cells, some of intermixed appearance with caulocystidia above.
-walls variable in color, often rather yellow in ammonia
-spores larceroid.

macro notes:
-Single specimen
-Habitat on very loose sandy soil, dominated by Quercus suber and plenty Pinus pinaster, Cistaceae around. Likely acidic. Around 115m above sea level.
-Obtuse low umbo. Cuticle brownish-gray, smooth to subsquamulose in disc, rather squamulose near margin
-Small grayish scales reveal warm rosey beige flesh underneath
-Stipe reddish-brown above, progrssively white towards equal to subclavate base. Faintly striate, rather tomentose all the way
-Lamellar insertion adnexed, pleura light brown (latte). Edge white, frosted to flocculose.
-Whitish context, with somewhat faint rose tints

results.notes:
Delightfully, this mushroom can be seen in this and nearby recreational areas most summers. It is typically near walking paths, sometimes close to streams. I have seen this associated with beech at Greenpoint Park, but here there are seldom beech, These were closest to oak, with maple, tulip poplar, hard packed clay soil, and a lake very nearby. Bright orange cap and white pores both staining brown on handling. Often clustered with very thick stems tapering to a point. These were smelly from maggots or too much rain but growing fine.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 146030827 on January 7, 2023.

results.notes:
Cap tan, tough. Context white slowly turning blue, bluer toward pores, then tan. Pores rapidly turning blue-black. Taste mild, slight acidic taste near pore layer, texture rubbery. Aroma pleasant mushroomy, attractive. Stipe yellow to tan, no reticulation, shadow of pink/red color. Following morning: There is not a shred of red in the cap at any age. As you can see in the slice, the oxidation was quickly blue fading to brown and fading to original yellow by morning. I’m guessing that the slugs and squirrels both like these mushrooms because of the abrasions and the stems scattered about with no caps. They are under what I call sourwood or Tupelo, photo of leaves included. All mushrooms lie under the canopy of the Tupelo, but there are oaks on every side of this small tree.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 146031202 on January 7, 2023.

results.notes:
Habitat: Growing terrestrially in open forest leaf litter among mixed deciduous hardwoods (beech, tulip and oak) in SE Pennsylvania; gregarious, sometimes in clusters; fruiting in two separate patches, each immediately adjacent to patches of more typically colored gray/brown/black Craterellus spp. Site elevation 350-400 ft above sea level.

Fruiting Body: 1-4 cm wide; 2-6 cm high; without a clearly defined cap and stem; tubular at first, becoming deeply vase-shaped; thin-fleshed and brittle; upper edge often flaring out or slightly rolled under, and sometimes spiraling inward.

Outer/Upper Surface: Peach or coral, sometimes lighter at the base; shallowly wrinkled; white basal mycelium.

Inner/Lower Surface: Initially the same color as the exterior, fading to white-ish with age; smooth to slightly bumpy or scaley.

Taste & Odor: Taste mild, odor not distinctive.

This seems like a rare naturally occurring color variation. I’ve yet to find references to Craterellus fallax displaying this sort of variation in the eastern US, but did find this recent European account of bright yellow C. cornucopioides.

If anyone else has additional research or first-hand accounts to share, I’d love to learn more.

results.notes: Mixed woods (oak, pine and palms) but nearest to oak. Virtually no scent was noticeable, not even a standard mushroom-y scent. Taste was instantly acrid and on the spicy side, feeling like I had bit my tongue before a slight numbness set in which then felt reminiscent of putting my tongue on a battery. The numb/tingling sensation lingered for upwards of 20 or so minutes. The cap was a bit sticky as well. The latex was initially white before slowly turning yellow and then later a grey green color. The inner flesh was white and turned yellowish before eventually (hours later) gaining green grey tints which I believe is from dried latex.

results.notes:
A few fruitbodies growing in short grass/moss under old oaks.
Cap cuticle barely peeling at margin. Taste mild. Unusual stipe surface. The caps are brown and gills are brownish-tan in the dried material. Collection saved and submitted for sequencing (ITS).
DNA sequencing results and discussion (posted on 20-Jun-22; last edited 14-Aug-23):
The ITS locus in this organism is a big mess, but the kind that can be pieced sorted out after a prolonged and patient analysis of the raw data. In summary, two main full-length ITS haplotypes were pieced together from the forward and reverse reads and posted to this observation. They share 10 mismatching positions, meaning that they are 98.4% similar. The sequences are technically joined contigs stitched together at the 2 nd point of heterogeneity, but the two reads actually share a 269 bp overlap because the heterogeneity in the reverse read was resolved well into ITS1 to get assignments for the first 3 isolated ambiguities. Also see Fig. 1 showing an alignment of the two haplotypes and marking the differences between them.
The major haplotype is present in a slightly larger quantity (~1.2:1 ratio from area under the curve) and is overall one base longer than the other. However, while a 1 base difference usually suggests a single point of heterogeneity, there are actually 3 points of heterogeneity seen in both reads (1 in the ITS1 sublocus and 2 in the ITS2 sublocus), two of which cancel each other out in terms of length gained/lost by either of the two haplotypes. In all 3 cases, the heterogeneity pattern is of the basic 1-base frame shift type, which can be easily followed and used for peak reassignments for a specific haplotype. One of the collateral benefits of sorting out the heterogeneity in the reverse read is that it allowed for the resolution of 7 individual ambiguities and their assignment to each haplotype (see Fig. 1).
So, was all this hard work justified? Yes, without a doubt. First, a search of the GenBank database revealed that there are no accessions labeled as “Russula ochroleucoides” (as of 20-Jun-22). Second, the haplotype sequences are only 96.4-97.0% similar to two accessions derived from the same Russula sp. voucher from Panama, KM594792 and KY548870. The genetic distance between two organisms suggests they are closely related, but not conspecific. Following these accessions, % similarity drops to <95% (several European records called Russula lepida).

results.notes:
A single fruiting body growing upside down from a steep, deep and exposed bank of a small stream running along the orange-blazed trail (the stream and trail are just 10-15 feet apart at this point). The GPS coordinates are approximate.
The cap is a perfect circle of 6 cm in diameter measured across the top, brownish-red (ca. 8C7 in Kornerup & Wanschler) and multi-zonate toward the margin. The curved stipe is 7 cm long from the point of gill attachment (measured with a string). Gills vivid lemon yellow, lamellulae plentiful and of variable length, staining bluish-green (or greenish-blue), then resolving brown. Upon sectioning, the shape of the mushroom resembled that of a gramophone speaker, with the cap and stipe being one continuous piece. The stipe, flaring at the top and gradually narrowing to a pointy tip at the base, is 1.6 cm wide at the point of gill attachment. The flesh is whitish, with some natural yellow, reddish & brownish pigmentation in the cap and stipe, respectively, already present at the time of sectioning (see photo). The flesh just above the gills, where it was already yellow along the entire length of gill attachment, slowly stained greenish (perhaps bluing over the yellow band of flesh gave an impression of green color). Basal mycelium appears white. Specimen preserved & will be sampled for DNA.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 14-Aug-22):
This collection was sample for ITS by Dr. Kudzma upon my request. The derived full-length nrITS sequence is of a joined contiguous type, meaning that the two reads are stitched together at some point. This is because there is a single point of heterogeneity at the very end of ITS2 region caused by a derailment at CTTT tandem repeat (this organism has 6 of these in row!). There are also 3 isolated ambiguities in the sequence.

results.notes:
Posted for illustrative purpose. Young Lanmaoa pallidorosea (smaller cap, wider stipe) can look very much like Baorangia bicolor (the other mushroom). I was on the verge of being fooled before noting the subtle differences in the gestalt. Of course, the ID was confirmed by the diagnostic odor present in the first mushroom.
By the way, M. Kuo’s B. bicolor page shows the same mix of taxa: https://www.mushroomexpert.com/boletus_bicolor.html (2nd & 6th pix are L. pallidorosea, IMO).
It would also be useful to point out a third player in this game, obs 327563, which represents an undescribed Lanmaoa sp. (by DNA) that looks like a bicolor-pallidorosea hybrid.

results.notes:
A single specimen collected by Magdalena Furniss. Maggie said that when she found the amanita, it was not yellow at all. The yellowing was brought on by applying pressure to the mushroom during touching/handling. Merely putting the mushroom down and making it rest against a hard surface produced the yellowing from the pressure points. When I brought the specimen home, it was even more yellow. Upon dissection, the flesh erratically yellowed, too.
In his website, RET describes the “yellowing syndrome” occurring with collections identified as A. subsolitaria: http://amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20subsolitaria (info in brief and tech tabs). Perhaps the “syndrome” is not limited to this species only. I now also recall coming across another such afflicted amanita in a totally different habitat and geographical area (i.e., not the Pine Barrens): obs 288558. I don’t know whether either of these two observations are A. subsolitaria or whether they are something else; they may not even be conspecific with each other. In the past I made numerous collections of “healthy” lepidellas in the NJ Pine Barrens fitting the concept of A. subsolitaria (morphologically and microscopically) that could actually be a mixture of taxa. I think RET is also of an opinion that subsolitaria could be a species group in need of resolution by DNA.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 23-May-21):
A 1420 nucleotide long fragment of the nrLSU gene was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this collection and posted by me here. It starts just before the ITS6R primer area and goes all the way to the LR7 primer area. The sequence is a “joined contig” of two long reads that share a 164-character common overlap.
This sequence is a 99.7% match (96% query cover) to Rod Tulloss’ accession of Amanita subsolitaria, HQ539750. This accession is still the sole high-value hit when only the first 933 characters are used for BLASTn-ing.
The species concept of Amanita subsolitaria (Murrill) Murrill, originally described from Florida, is rather nebulous given the author’s brief description and the presence of other similar-looking species (some cryptic) with close spore dimensions in the pine-oak habitat along the Atlantic coastal plain from the Gulf Coast area north to NJ.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 21-Feb-21; updated 23-Feb-21):
Results: A clean full-length nrITS sequence of 593 bps fully supported by 1 forward and 1 reverse reads was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma and posted to this observation. It’s flanked by short SSU & LSU fragments that contain the primers used for DNA amplification and sequencing. There are no ambiguities, it’s a single haplotype.
This sequence is 99.14-99.83% similar to 9 accessions, of which:
- 5 are labeled as ‘Amanita canescens’ (4 of these are by RET and are derived from 2 vouchers, so half of these are duplicate accessions)
- 2 are labeled as ‘Amanita radiata’ (1 of these by RET)
- 1 as ‘Amanita media’ (by RET)
Discussion: A. canescens, A. media and A. radiata were all described by D. T. Jenkins from Alabama.1, 2, 3 It’s not clear if these taxa naturally have very close sequences or if some of the the vouchers in GenBank have been misidentified and all these accessions, in fact, represent a single, geographically widespread taxon. RET suggests radiata and media are probably the same entity, as both protologues were collected by Jenkins on the same day from the same location (Covington Co. Rest Area on US-331 between Florala and Opp, AL); if conspecific, media prevails by virtue of being the older name. However, despite the essentially identical ITS sequences, canescens and media / radiata are still treated as separate taxa, as their spore profiles are different. Jenkins’ types of these three species have not yet been sequenced. Upon Jenkins’ retirement from Univ. of Alabama several years ago, his collections may have been transferred to an institutional herbarium.
References:
1 Mycotaxon 14(1): 233 (1982)
2 Mycotaxon 16(2): 414 (1983)
3 Mycotaxon 20(2): 315 (1984)
